13:44 <spu7nic> Hi :)  
13:44 <vmassol> has joined #xwiki  
13:46 <spu7nic> How would be the best way to set computed default values for class properties?  
13:47 <spu7nic> Put some velocity code into the template?  
13:48 <spu7nic> Or is it possible (I've seen it on some existing title fields) to use velocity within the field itself?  
13:54 <DarkKnightCZ> has joined #xwiki  
14:01 <mflorea> has quit  
14:01 <evalica> has quit  
14:16 <polx> has joined #xwiki  
14:30 <mflorea> has joined #xwiki  
14:31 <cjd> mflorea: if I were to propose we deprecate use of object inheritence in js, what would your reaction be?  
14:33 <cjd> sdumitriu: same question, although I suspect I know what you'll say xD  
14:34 <cjd> My reasoning is #1 OI is more difficult to maintain than composition in the best of cases (page 20 of GoF "Favor object composition over inheritance")  
14:35 <cjd> #2 the new and prototype keywords in js are nasty traps  
14:35 <cjd> you can write code which \*looks\* like java but if you walk an inch off the beaten path, you're going to be debugging it for weeks  
14:41 <polx\_> has joined #xwiki  
14:43 <polx> has quit  
14:45 <polx> has quit  
14:46 <polx> has joined #xwiki  
14:46 <vmassol> has quit  
14:46 <polx> has quit  
15:13 <polx> has joined #xwiki  
15:14 <vmassol> has joined #xwiki  
15:23 <KermitTheFragger> has quit  
15:27 <KermitTheFragger> has joined #xwiki  
15:35 <evalica> has joined #xwiki  
15:46 <mflorea> cjd: I don't think it makes sense to 'deprecate' a programming principle like object inheritance independent of the framework/library used to achieve it and independent of the use case. There may be cases where object inheritance is not needed (an overkill) and other cases where it may be very useful.  
15:48 <cjd> with any broad deprecation we have to consider edge cases and give the programmer leaway  
15:48 <cjd> for example (new Array(30).join(' ')) is really the best way to get 30 spaces  
15:49 <cjd> and new WebSocket() is required to get a websocket  
15:49 <cjd> but in general, code using: new, prototype, constructor and this  is much more likely to have bugs (imo) than code which avoids it  
15:49 <cjd> \*them  
15:51 <gdelhumeau> why xwiki-platform-5.4.x still not work?  
15:53 <tmortagne> packager plugin as usual it seems, but look like I can't get it back on track this time, I restarted it already and it did not fix the build  
15:53 <gdelhumeau> yes, we restart it for several days already, without success  
15:54 <mflorea> http://ci.xwiki.org/job/xwiki-platform-5.4.x/ws/xwiki-platform-tools/xwiki-platform-tool-packager-plugin/target/it/package-simple/build.log  
15:54 <mflorea> why is it still using 5.4.3-SNAPSHOT?  
15:54 <mflorea> should be 5.4.4-SNAPSHOT no?  
15:55 <tmortagne> yes should be 5.4.4-SNAPSHOT  
15:55 <tmortagne> and that' what is the project version according to the log  
15:56 <tmortagne> no idea where it found 5.4.3-SNAPSHOT  
15:59 <tmortagne> most of the thing packager plugin listed are 5.4.4-SNAPSHOT  
15:59 <tmortagne> but some are 5.4.3-SNAPSHOT  
15:59 <tmortagne> org.xwiki.commons:xwiki-commons-configuration-api for example  
16:00 <tmortagne> all commons and rendering it seems, but the platform parent version is right  
16:00 <tmortagne> cheking commons pom  
16:00 <tmortagne> still org.xwiki.platform:xwiki-platform-tool-jetty-resources is not commons or rendering  
16:01 <msmeria> has quit  
16:02 <tmortagne> I think I fixed the issue but packager plugin i still pretty buggy in its dependencies management

18:00 <woshilapin> has quit  
18:03 <Sidali\_> has joined #xwiki  
18:05 <sdumitriu> cjd: Hm, do you mean not use it in new code, or rewrite existing widgets?  
18:05 <Sidali> has quit  
18:05 <cjd> new code  
18:05 <Sidali\_> is now known as <Sidali>  
18:05 <sdumitriu> cjd: If you can formulate a nice "XWiki best practice" for creating new widgets, +1  
18:06 <sdumitriu> Inheritance is just a means to an end: extend base functionality without copying code  
18:06 <sdumitriu> If there's a better means to the same end, all the better  
18:06 <cjd> I do  Thing.create()  
18:06 <cjd> because it's much safer than new Thing()  
18:06 <cjd> and then I avoid 'prototype', 'new', 'this', and 'constructor'  
18:06 <cjd> (in general, exceptions abound)  
18:07 <sdumitriu> +1 for avoiding those, except "this"  
18:08 <cjd> what's your usecase for it?  
18:08 <cjd> assigning crap to functions is scary  
18:14 <sdumitriu> Well, being able to call other functions on the same object  
18:16 <Chuguniy> has quit  
18:17 <cjd> I was taught to have a "constructor" which returns a {} and then put your function pointers (if you so desire) into the {}  
18:17 <sdumitriu> And how do you access it?  
18:17 <sdumitriu> From within those functions?  
18:18 <cjd> ahh, I pass objects to my functions  
18:18 <cjd> err wait  
18:18 <cjd> there's a way  
18:18 <cjd> make all of your functions inner to your constructor function  
18:18 <cjd> I still pass objects to my functions :)  
18:19 <vmassol> has quit  
18:24 <tmortagne> has quit  
18:28 <sdumitriu> cjd: OK, show me an example and I'll tell you what I think  
18:29 <cjd> https://github.com/xwiki-contrib/chainpad/blob/master/client/Message.js  
18:29 <cjd> this is actually pure C style  
18:29 <cjd> I'm happy to have people doing function pointers by wrapping all of the inside functions inside of Message.create so that they can call msg.doStuff() as expected  
18:30 <sdumitriu> Why is there PARANOIA in the code?  
18:30 <sdumitriu> :D  
18:31 <sdumitriu> But seriously, what's that supposed to mean?  
18:31 <cjd> enable (or disable) tons of checks which will cause it to blow up way earlier if there is a bug  
18:35 <sdumitriu> I see, so the essense is that:  
18:36 <sdumitriu> - from Thing functions you just call the functions by their names, relying on the fact that they're in the same scope  
18:37 <sdumitriu> - from OtherThing functions you call them as Thing.method(thingInstance, otherParams)  
18:37 <cjd> I'd sign off on this pattern:    MyObj.create = function () {  var out = {};  var doStuff = out.doStuff = function () { .... };    return out; };  
18:38 <sdumitriu> - from ExtendedThing.method(extendedThing) you call Thing.method(extendedThing) to call the super  
18:39 <cjd> I would be really wary of any 'extends'  
18:39 <cjd> it's always causing problems IMO  
18:39 <cjd> oh I see, you're talking about composition  
18:39 <cjd> yeah, that's acceptable  
18:40 <sdumitriu> Yes  
18:40 <sdumitriu> Fake "Inheritance" through composition, yes  
18:41 <cjd> In js, my feeling is you probably don't need inheritence and people are likely to just use it because it's the hammer at the top of the tool bucket  
18:43 <vmassol> has joined #xwiki  
18:52 <abusenius> has joined #xwiki

18:57 <mflorea> I hope
